lore1.title: 20 Jan 2025 - NOT YET STARTED, ALREADY CHANGED.

Like all my projects, I've gone big right out of the gateâ€”and yes, I'm already stressed. Not sure if that's a good thing or not. But hey, I'm having fun, so maybe it's okay. Hopefully, this will turn into something therapeuticâ€”a little diary for all the things I love doing.

terrarium1.title: The right mixture
content: The first time I made a terrarium, I failed spectacularly ðŸ¥€. I thought I could just throw some plants into a jar, and they'd thrive. Spoiler: they didn't. Despite having some basic plant knowledge [I'm no perfect plant mom, but I try!], my first attempt turned into a moldy disaster.

Terrariums, I learned, are about balanceâ€”and soil is at the heart of that. It's not just dirt; it's the foundation for everything. The right mixture creates the environment where plants can grow, water can circulate, and the whole ecosystem can thrive.

Take this terrarium in the picture, for example. It's âœ¨preciousâœ¨ to me because it holds pebbles and a snail shell from my [now lost] childhood home. I refused to give up on it after my initial failures.
Attempt One lasted three weeks. Mold everywhere, rotting fittonia, and stagnant water pooling at the bottom
Attempt Two failed almost immediately, after few days the colors and balance were all wrong.
Attempt Three? It thrived for five years before needing a refreshâ€”and it's still alive and well today ðŸ’š.

The secret? A lot of trial and errorâ€”and discovering how much the right soil matters. Good soil doesn't just anchor the plants; it helps regulate water, prevents mold, and provides the nutrients needed for long-term health. A terrarium isn't just a pretty jar; it's an ecosystem. Get the soil mixture right, and the rest falls into place.

terrarium2.title: The tiny world
content: Those tiny jars of greenery? They're like a whole world in miniature, and honestly, I could cry from the cuteness. ðŸŒ¿

I've made these little treasures for all kinds of gifts, and they're always a hit. There's just something magical about a tiny, self-contained ecosystem that never fails to captivate people. It's also proof that size really doesn't matter â€”eheh.

This last batch I made in autumn 2024 is currently surviving the harsh conditions of my terribly exposed office window (a true test of resilience). They just stretched a little bit, ready to be trimmed in springtime. ðŸŒ±
